sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• usual dosage is 250 mg every 6 hours (delayed-release capsules) or 333 mg orally every 8 hours (oral tablets); 500 mg orally every 12 hours may be used; may titrate up to 4 g per day based on severity of infection; twice daily dosing not recommended with doses greater than 1 g per day
  • Acne vulgaris: (gel) apply to affected area TOPICALLY once to twice daily; or (ointment, solution and pads) twice daily after skin is thoroughly cleansed and patted dry
  • Allergy to penicillin - Rheumatic fever; Prophylaxis: 250 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • Bacterial infection of eye: 1 cm ribbon OPHTHALMIC ointment applied up to 6 times daily (depending on severity of infection)
  • Bartonellosis - HIV infection: (bacillary angiomatosis, peliosis hepatis, bacteremia, osteomyelitis) 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for at least 3 months
  • Chancroid: 500 mg ORALLY 3 times a day for 7 days
  • Chlamydial infection: 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily OR 666 mg ORALLY every 8 hours for at least 7 days
  • Diphtheria, adjunct to antitoxin; Adjunct: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr or 333 mg every 8 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Erythrasma: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day or 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 333 mg ORALLY every 8 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Female gonococcal pelvic inflammatory disease: erythromycin lactobionate 500 mg IV every 6 hr for 3 days FOLLOWED by oral erythromycin 250 mg every 6 hr or 333 mg ORALLY every 8 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr for 7 days
  • Granuloma inguinale: 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for at least 3 weeks and until all lesions have completely healed
  • Impetigo: (Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species) 250 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for 7 days, depending on clinical response (guideline dosing)
  • Infection due to Entamoeba histolytica - Intestinal infectious disease: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr or 333 mg ORALLY every 8 hr for 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Mild to Moderate) - Soft tissue infection: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day or 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 333 mg ORALLY every 8 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Legionnaires disease: 1 to 4 g ORALLY in divided doses
  • Listeriosis: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr or 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 333 mg ORALLY every 8 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Lyme disease: (alternative to first-line) 500 mg ORALLY four times daily for 14 to 21 days for early localized or early disseminated Lyme disease associated with erythema migrans, or borrelial lymphocytoma
  • Lymphogranuloma venereum: 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for 21 days
  • Nongonococcal urethritis: 500 mg ORALLY 4 times daily for 7 days (guideline dosing) OR 666 mg ORALLY every 8 hours for at least 7 days (manufacturer dosing)
  • Pertussis: 40 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses for 5 to 14 days (manufacturer dosing) OR 2 g/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses for 14 days (guideline dosing)
  • Respiratory tract infection: 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day or 250 mg ORALLY every 6 hr or 333 mg ORALLY every 8 hr or 500 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; MAX 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Syphilis: 30 to 40 g ORALLY in divided doses over 10 to 15 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono:
• usual dosage 30 to 50 mg/kg/day orally in equally divided doses; for more severe infections, dose may be doubled; do not exceed 4 g per day
  • Allergy to penicillin - Rheumatic fever; Prophylaxis: 250 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • Bacterial infection of eye: 1 cm ribbon OPHTHALMIC ointment applied up to 6 times daily (depending on severity of infection)
  • Bartonellosis - HIV infection: (cutaneous bacillary angiomatosis) 30 to 50 mg/kg/day (MAX 2 g/day) ORALLY divided into 2 to 4 doses/day for 3 months
  • Chlamydial infection: (children less than 45 kg) 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 4 doses daily for 14 days
  • Diphtheria, adjunct to antitoxin; Adjunct: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in equally divided doses; the dosage may be doubled for more severe infections but should not exceed 4 g/day, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Erythrasma: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided every 6 to 8 hr; MAX 4 g/day as base, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Gonococcal conjunctivitis neonatorum; Prophylaxis: 1 cm ribbon of OPHTHALMIC ointment applied to each lower conjunctival sac; during drug shortage, 1 to 2 drops of azithromycin 1% ophthalmic solution placed in the conjunctival sac of each EYE is recommended
  • Impetigo: (Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species) 40 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 3 or 4 divided doses for 7 days, depending on clinical response (guideline dosing)
  • Infection due to Entamoeba histolytica - Intestinal infectious disease: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses over 10 to 14 days
  • Infection of skin AND/OR subcutaneous tissue (Mild to Moderate) - Soft tissue infection: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided every 6 to 8 hr; MAX 4 g/day as base, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Legionnaires disease: 1 to 4 g ORALLY in divided doses
  • Listeriosis: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided every 6 to 8 hr; MAX 4 g/day as base, depending on type and severity of infection
  • Lyme disease: (alternative to first-line) 12.5 mg/kg ORALLY four times daily for 14 to 21 days for early localized or early disseminated Lyme disease associated with erythema migrans, or borrelial lymphocytoma; maximum daily dose, 2000 mg
  • Neonatal chlamydial conjunctivitis: 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses for 14 days
  • Neonatal chlamydial conjunctivitis; Prophylaxis: 1 cm ribbon of OPHTHALMIC ointment applied to each lower conjunctival sac; during drug shortage, 1 to 2 drops of azithromycin 1% ophthalmic solution placed in the conjunctival sac of each EYE is recommended
  • Neonatal chlamydial pneumonia: 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY divided into 4 doses daily for 14 days
  • Pertussis: 40 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses for 5 to 14 days (manufacturer dosing); 14 days preferred to avoid risk of relapse; MAX 2 g/day; use not recommended if younger than 1 month (alternative is azithromycin) (guideline dosing)
  • Respiratory tract infection: 30 to 50 mg/kg/day ORALLY in divided doses; may double the dose for severe infections; MAX 4 g/day
  • Respiratory tract infection: (community acquired pneumonia; older than 3 months of age) 40 mg/kg/day ORALLY in 4 divided doses (guideline dosing)
  • Syphilis: 30 to 40 g ORALLY in divided doses over 10 to 15 days

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: hepatic impairment: drug may accumulate in patients with severe liver disease; no specific dosing recommendations available

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant therapy with astemizole, cisapride, dihydroergotamine, ergotamine, pimozide, or terfenadine
  • hypersensitivity to erythromycin or any component of the product

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea, including mild diarrhea to fatal colitis, has been reported; may occur 2 months or more after discontinuation; may need to discontinue ongoing use if suspected
  • elderly patients, especially with renal or hepatic dysfunction; increased risk of erythromycin-associated hearing loss
  • elderly patients; increased risk of QT prolongation and torsades de pointes
  • hepatic impairment; increased risk of toxicity
  • hepatotoxicity (eg, increased liver enzymes, and hepatocellular and/or cholestatic hepatitis, with or without jaundice) has been reported
  • infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) has been reported
  • myasthenia gravis, exacerbation, and new-onset myasthenic syndrome has been reported
  • prolonged or repeated use; overgrowth of nonsusceptible bacteria or fungi (ie, superinfection) may occur; discontinue use
  • QT interval prolongation, including rare cases of arrhythmia, torsade de pointes, and fatalities, has been reported; avoid use with known QT prolongation, uncorrected hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia, clinically significant bradycardia, and with Class IA (quinidine, procainamide), or Class III (dofetilide, amiodarone, sotalol) antiarrhythmic agents

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• AAP: Maternal medication usually compatible with breastfeeding.
  • WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea, Loss of appetite, Nausea, Stomach cramps, Vomiting
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Cardiac dysrhythmia, Prolonged QT interval, Torsades de pointes, Ventricular arrhythmia, Ventricular tachycardia
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis due to drug
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile colitis, Pancreatitis
  • Hepatic:Cholestatic hepatitis, Hepatitis
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis
  • Neurologic:Seizure
  • Otic:Ototoxicity
  • Renal:Interstitial nephritis

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome in susceptible organisms.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, oral: 4 hours
  • Bioavailability, oral: varies by salt
  • Effects of food: Cmax reduced by 73% and AUC reduced by 72%

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Bile: primary excretion
  • Renal: less than 5% unchanged
  • Dialysis: No (hemodialysis); No (peritoneal dialysis)
  • Hemofiltration: Yes, 37% removed

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Oral
    • may be taken with or without meals
    • (delayed-release) swallow whole; do not crush or chew
  • Topical
    (gel) avoid contact with eyes and all mucous membranes

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement, resolution of fever or elevated WBC
  • creatine kinase and transaminase serum concentrations; in patients receiving concomitant lovastatin therapy

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
OVERDOSE: Significant toxicity following acute overdose is uncommon. N/V, abdominal pain may occur. ADVERSE EFFECTS: N/V, abdominal pain, diarrhea most common. Cholestasis, sensorineural hearing loss, thrombophlebitis (IV administration), ventricular dysrhythmias/QT prolongation (IV administration) are less common.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage.
  • Support: Therapy as indicated.
  • Abdominal discomfort: Food, milk or an antacid may be given; most effects reverse with drug cessation
  • Monitoring of patient: Baseline ECG, cardiac monitoring as indicated. Renal and hepatic function as indicated.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
MACROLIDE ANTIBIOTICS
In general, the macrolide antibiotics are of a low order toxicity.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause loss of appetite, nausea, stomach cramps, or vomiting.
  • Elderly patients are more susceptible to development of dysrhythmia and torsade de pointes.
  • Elderly patients with renal or hepatic dysfunction are at increased risk of ototoxicity.
  • Instruct patient to report severe diarrhea and consult healthcare professional prior to taking anti-diarrhea medicine.
  • Elderly patients on concomitant anticoagulant therapy should monitor for signs/symptoms of bleeding, as drug may have additive effects.
  • Patients with a history of myasthenia gravis should report signs/symptoms of disease exacerbation during therapy.
  • Patients using the topical gel should avoid contact with eyes and all mucous membranes.
  • Do not use with astemizole, cisapride, pimozide, terfenadine, or lovastatin.
